chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reforming the Electoral College should aim to reflect the national will more closely while keeping states central to administering elections and ensuring smaller communities aren’t written off. A broadly acceptable path is to keep the Electoral College but curb winner-take-all by encouraging proportional or district-based elector allocation, and/or adopting the National Popular Vote compact once it has broad, bipartisan state participation. Any reform should be paired with baseline national rules for ballot access, transparent recount triggers, and routine post‑election audits so close outcomes are both verifiable and widely accepted.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should make every vote matter more evenly while preserving the state-based, federal character many people value and keeping elections stable and understandable. A practical compromise is to keep the Electoral College but reduce winner-take-all by allocating each state’s electors proportionally or by district, require electors to follow the state’s certified popular vote, and pair this with clear, uniform standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and recounts. These steps would lessen swing‑state distortion, improve transparency and trust, and help results feel legitimate in both rural and urban communities.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should make presidential elections feel fairer and less “winner‑take‑all” while preserving the states’ role in administering elections and ensuring smaller communities aren’t ignored. A broad compromise is to keep the Electoral College but have states allocate electors proportionally (or by district with safeguards against gerrymandering) and require electors to follow the voters’ choice, alongside clear national baseline standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and recount triggers. If states prefer a national popular vote approach, the National Popular Vote compact could be paired with the same uniform integrity and recount rules so outcomes are transparent, predictable, and widely accepted.
